awd_titl_txt: Braided Tensor Categories, Their Structures, Symmetries, and Graded Extensions
awd_abstract_narration:
This project concerns the study of tensor categories. These  are mathematical structures consisting of objects that can be added and multiplied using certain natural rules.  The abstract nature of these structures makes them a very convenient tool to study symmetries, both in the classical and quantum arenas. Recently, tensor categories were proposed as mathematical models of a topological quantum computation, one of the most promising models for the construction of a quantum computer. They are also closely related to symmetries of topological phases of matter and are used to predict the existence of new types of such phases and their physical realization. This project deals with algebraic aspects of the theory of tensor categories: their structure, classification, and arithmetic properties. The emphasis is on categories that are most widely used in applications. Such categories admit an additional symmetry constraint called braiding that is used to model interaction of pairs of quantum particles. 

Tensor categories provide a unified framework for studying various quantum symmetries such as quantum groups, vertex operator algebras, Jones-von Neumann subfactors,and conformal field theories. Categorical methods in the theory of Hopf algebras and quantum groups led to a number of important classification results and continue to bring forth new insights.  This project will use the machinery that has already been developed to approach fundamental questions concerning the structure and classification of tensor categories. It will address problems related to extensions of braided tensor categories, their modules, and groups of symmetries. The concrete areas of research include the following:  (1) the theory of graded extensions of braided tensor categories and classification of minimal non-degenerate extensions, (2) the Picard groups of braided tensor categories and their actions on categorical orthogonal Grassmannians with applications to the representation categories of small quantum groups; (3) arithmetic properties and structure of fusion categories and semisimple Hopf algebras; (4) classification of non-semisimple pointed braided tensor categories and their module categories.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Tensor categories are algebraic objects that appear in many different areas of mathematics and physics. They provide adequate language for describing various non-commutative, or "quantum," symmetries. Here are a few examples. In low-dimensional topology, braided tensor categories encode invariants of knots and 3-manifolds. In the theory of von Neumann algebras tensor categories describe symmetries of extensions, i.e., play the same role as groups in Galois theory.  In quantum statistics, braided tensor categories are used to describe systems of elementary particles. The tensor product corresponds to a fusion of such particles ? hence the name fusion category. The braiding describes the process of looping one particle around another and altering its quantum state. Categories with non-degenerate braiding were proposed as mathematical models of topological quantum computation.

The goal of this project was to study the algebraic structure of braided tensor categories and investigate their invariants. Some of the problems considered by the PI, such as the finiteness of images of braid group representations  and computation of the groups of minimal non-degenerate extensions, were motivated by applications to quantum computation and the classification of topological phases of matter.

The main results of this project are the following. (1) The theory of graded extensions of braided fusion categories was developed, jointly with Davydov, and the new notion of a braided categorical Picard group was introduced. This group controls all such extensions and generalizes previously known low-dimensional examples of Picard groups. (2) In joint work with Green, the image of the braid group representation associated with a weakly group-theoretical fusion category was shown to be finite. This result settles a conjecture that was open for more than a decade.  (3) Braidings on fusion categories were classified in geometric terms. (4) The groups of minimal non-degenerate extensions of pointed symmetric categories were explicitly computed (these groups describe  symmetry-protected topological phases of matter). These results and new techniques developed by the PI in the framework of this project constitute its intellectual merit.

Graduate and undergraduate students were involved in closely related work, thus the project contributed to the development of the next generation of experts. Outcomes of this project were presented  at several international and domestic conferences and seminars.

The PI gave introductory lectures to math and physics graduate students and postdocs (e.g., at the MSRI program on quantum symmetries in Spring 2020 and the IPAM summer school on topological phases of matter in 2021). The PI interacted with theoretical physicists on topics directly related to this project. An example of such interaction is a recent ESI workshop on Higher Structures and Field Theory. The PI also co-organized an Oberwolfach workshop in 2021 that brought together international researchers in operator algebras, tensor categories, and quantum groups. These constitute the broader impacts of the project.
